abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the HIV/AIDS Project for
            Cape Verde were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: A multi-sectoral strategy requires
            does not mean that the funding should not be targeted. The
            Bank should focus support for implementation on those
            sectors where activities have the greatest potential impact
            on the epidemic and with some comparative advantage in
            implementation such as the Ministry of Health, and those
            ministries related to the military, education, and
            transport. Implementation of a multi-sectoral strategy
            requires that roles and responsibilities (along with the
            accompanying human and financial resources) be defined and
            respected by the various public and private actors. While
            the project succeeded in building capacity through
            traditional means its greater success may have been in
            focusing on facilitation and coordination rather than
            command and control. It is a challenge to ensure political
            commitment to target vulnerable populations. The key to
            maintaining political commitment at all levels are not
            necessarily compatible with improving the targeting of
            vulnerability factors. The transition from: (i) information
            and sensitization of the general population to; and (ii)
            support for more focused groups (women, youths, orphans, etc.).

abstracts.cdata!:
This additional financing for Cape Verde
            HIV/AIDS project satisfies the conditions for additional
            financing for investment lending: (a) it will support
            activities that will increase the project's impact in a
            manner consistent with the Project Appraisal Document (PAD)
            presented to the Board in March 2002; (b) the current IDA
            financed project is properly implemented; (c) activities to
            be financed have shown results under the ongoing project;
            and (d) the closing date will be within the limit of three
            years after closing of the initial project. The additional
            financing will also help set up mechanisms to ensure
            sustainability after project completion.

repnme.cdata!:
Cape Verde - Projet VIH/SIDA : gestion des
            dechets biomedicaux

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will support the national
            strategy to combat the incidence, and impact of HIV/AIDS in
            Cape Verde, by minimizing socioeconomic impacts at the
            individual, family, and community levels. The main project
            objectives will include initiatives by the public, and
            private sectors to strengthen the institutional framework,
            and build capacities responsive to the epidemic. However,
            the presence of biomedical wastes within the framework of
            the project, poses adverse environmental impacts, due to the
            potential, inadequate handling of infected materials. This
            environmental assessment addresses specifically the
            management of biomedical wastes, and examines the
            institutional capacity within health institutions and local
            authorities, to propose a feasible plan of action, to reduce
            HIV/AIDS infection risks. Measures to mitigate biomedical
            wastes disposal are as follows. Institutional, legal and
            regulatory frameworks will be strengthened through
            inter-governmental efforts by the Environment, Agriculture
            and Public Health ministries to implement, and enforce
            environmentally sound waste management practices. Health
            facilities will be provided with sanitary equipment for the
            collection, and removal of biomedical wastes, as well as
            trained personnel in precautionary practices for handling
            infected, or non-sterilized medical wastes, and, the choice
            of small incinerators will be available for hospital uses.
            Moreover, training and specific programs will be available
            for health providers, to develop awareness on the direct,
            and indirect risks of inappropriate wastes handling.
            Effluent discharges will undergo adequate treatment at the
            municipal level, including systematic incineration plans,
            and compacted waste disposal. Public awareness will aim at
            sensitizing communities on the related risks between AIDS
            and biomedical waste disposal.

docna.cdata!:
Cape Verde - Projet VIH/SIDA : gestion des
            dechets biomedicaux

display_title.display_title:
Cap Vert – Projet VIH/SIDA :
            gestion des déchets biomédicaux

1804995.subsc: Health,Other social services,Sub-national government administration,Central government administration

abstracts.cdata!:
This project supports the goal of the
            national HIV/AIDS strategy of the government of Cape Verde,
            which is to reduce the spread of HIV infection in the
            country. To achieve this goal, the project will also support
            the following objectives: 1) mitigation of the health and
            socio-economic impact of HIV/AIDS at individual, household,
            and community levels, thus sustaining an economically
            productive population; and 2) establishment of a strong and
            sustainable national capacity to respond to the epidemic.
            Under the regional MAP II (report no. 20727), this project
            finances HIV/AIDS activities for the period 2002-2006. It
            has four components that reflect the two-tiered
            decentralized administrative sstructure in Cape Verde at
            national and municipal levels. Apart from the component on
            project facilitation, coordination, monitoring, and
            evaluation (which will support facilitation and coordination
            of the project), each of the remaining three components
            supports the full spectrum of HIV/AIDS prevention,
            treatment, care, and support activities that are appropriate
            at the respective level. The other three project components
            are: capacity building, public sector initiatives, and civil
            society and private sector initiatives.
